Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Ethnicity and Locality: Linguistic Variation and Practices among a Vietnamese American Student Group

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
How do ethnic minorities in the U.S. maintain their cultural identity as they integrate into American society? This dissertation research will focus on the linguistic practices of Vietnamese-American students at a university in Minnesota. Previous sociolinguistic studies of Asian Americans in the U.S. have focused on East Asians; other Asian groups are largely unstudied, even though Southeast Asians comprise the majority of the local Asian-American community in some parts of the country, such as the Twin Cities area in Minnesota. Previous research has shown that Southeast Asians may view themselves differently, as indicated by the use of references such as "the other Asian" or "new wave", terms that highlight a distinction from other Asian groups.

Three questions guide this research: First, in what ways do members of this organization draw upon linguistic features in constructing their identities both within the organization and in their local community? Second, is there evidence that these speakers use features tied to their heritage language? Third, what practices orient speakers to or away from definitions of "Vietnamese" and "Asian American"? Data for this study will be collected from members of this organization as well as control groups of European Americans and native Vietnamese. Speech data includes individual interviews, group discussions, and spontaneous speech collected in naturalistic settings. Speech data will be complemented by ethnographic information collected through participant observation.

From the point of view of sociolinguistic theory, the purpose of this research is to examine how speakers negotiate a diverse set of identities within the bounds of a specific community and how shared experiences shape the social meaning of linguistic variation. This research will add to our knowledge of the linguistic practices of Asian Americans and emphasize the wide range of histories and cultures that this label encompasses. This research will also focus attention on the varied identities with which ethnic minorities may align themselves.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The study of ethnicity within sociolinguistics is a well developed area of research, and in our quest to understand similarities and differences across ethnic lines, two questions have surfaced to understand how linguistic variation may play a role: 1) Do ethnic minority groups pattern with European Americans with regard to language change? and 2) Do ethnic minority speakers make use of linguistic features that signal their ethnic identity? A sizeable body of work exists to address these two questions with focus on African American and Latino communities in the United States alone, but while Asian Americans now comprise the fastest growing segment of the U.S. population, they have been relatively understudied until more recently (see Chun, 2001; Wong, 2007; Hall-Lew, 2009; Reyes and Lo, 2009). Beginning to ask questions regarding the linguistic and social practices of Asian Americans requires an acknowledgement of the diversity within the “Asian American” label. This is a group unified by a vast area of the world from which they originate, but those who may identify as Asian American come from diverse cultural, historical, and linguistic backgrounds. In acknowledgment of this diversity, this research aims to add to the growing body of work on Asian Americans by focusing attention on Vietnamese Americans.

The speakers in this study are members of a Vietnamese American Student Organization (VASO) at a university in Minnesota, and as members of an ethnically identified organization, they engage in the representation of culture through organization activities. This group of individuals represents a community of practice (Eckert and McConnell-Ginet, 1992) through which the linguistic and social practices of members provide insights into how ethnic identity may be constructed. Framing a community of speakers in this way also facilitates the examination of possible links between linguistic variation and ethnic identity.

Specifically, this research questions whether members of VASO participate in local sound change and/or use linguistic features tied to the ethnic identity of members. Features under investigation include /æ/-raising and /l/-vocalization. The low front vowel, /æ/, is subject to raising in areas exhibiting the Northern Cities Shift (NCS), a vowel chain shift in which the shifting of /æ/ may be one of the initial stages (Labov, Ash, and Boberb, 2006). Further, /l/-vocalization, in which /l/ becomes vowel-like or is not pronounced at all, is a noted substrate feature found across different varieties of English and has been posited as a feature of English spoken by some Asian Americans (Hall-Lew, 2009).

Coupling linguistic analysis with ethnographic observations illuminates how language variation is intertwined with identity construction, and in light of this, data consisted of ethnographic observations and interview recordings with individual VASO members throughout the full length of an academic year.  A total of 26 members of VASO participated in this research, and interviews were also recorded with two comparison groups: European American students and Vietnamese international students studying at the same university. There were a total of 21 interviews collected from these two comparison groups. Linguistic analyses proceeded with features extracted from speech recorded during interviews.

In regards to /æ/-raising, data suggest that /æ/ is shifting among VASO and European Americans in line with predictions of the NCS, but it is not as progressive in comparison to areas known to have the NCS. Logistic regression analyses also show that ethnicity is a significant factor, with VASO speakers raising less than European American speakers.
